newsitem.title: USA: Indiana corn harvest 16 days behind average pace.
newsitem.headline: Indiana corn harvest 16 days behind average pace.

text.p: Indiana's corn harvest was 16 days behind average and soybeans were 14 days behind as wet weather kept combines out of the fields, the state's Agricultural Statistics Service said.
Corn was 32 percent harvested as of Sunday, down from 61 percent for the five-year average. Average moisture content of harvested corn was reported at 24 percent.

Soybeans were 67 percent harvested as of Sunday, compared with 91 percent for the five-year average. Average moisture content was estimated at 13 percent. Nearly all the soybean acreage was mature except for double-crop fields.
Winter wheat was 78 percent seeded, against 87 percent for the five-year average. The crop was rated 52 percent good to excellent, compared with 49 percent last year.
Pasture was rated two percent excellent, 32 percent good, 51 percent fair, 12 percent poor and three percent very poor.
Soil moisture was rated one percent very short, five percent short, 85 percent adequate and nine percent surplus.
There were 4.7 days suitable for fieldwork.
